verified with browser that ressources don't exist
David, Callisto is missing some files.

Andreas, how are you accessing these? Via mirror? 
I just tried, and all the right files seem to be there. 
But the "right" file for GEF is 3.2.0.v20060616, not 
3.2.0.v20060529, so, I'm wondering where that's coming from? 

I wonder if its an issue with mirrors or "cached" copies somewhere on your  internet?

Oh, and Andreas, just in case you think related, if you accessed the site just before the updates to RC5 level were made, but did not restart for some reason, I think some values are cached there locally, so you will have to restart Eclpse for it to uncache them and get the new values (we expect this to happen 'naturally', most of the time, but thought I'd mention, in case its related).

Comment #3 doesn't apply, but using network monitoring I've found the following:

GET http://download.eclipse.org/callisto/releases/site.xml retrieves the list of mirror sites/ features and this is what the proxy's response is:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Age: 466959
Accept-Ranges: bytes
Date: Wed, 21 Jun 2006 05:59:39 GMT
Content-Length: 11508
Content-Type: text/xml
Warning: 113 MHPAKAHC "Heuristic expiration"
Server: Apache
Last-Modified: Fri, 09 Jun 2006 03:00:25 GMT
ETag: "e513-2cf4-415c1cd5ae440"
Via: 1.1 MHPAKAHC (NetCache NetApp/5.6.2D13)

It seems the proxy is serving old content here- or might this be an issue with the eclipse HTTP client?

Or potentially the callisto update web server configuration? Forcing reload via web browser now brings the expected result:

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Age: 3
Date: Mon, 26 Jun 2006 15:46:33 GMT
Content-Length: 11016
Content-Type: text/xml
Server: Apache
Last-Modified: Sun, 25 Jun 2006 07:41:29 GMT
ETag: "aa171-2b08-4170797fd1c40"
Via: 1.1 MHPAKAHC (NetCache NetApp/5.6.2D13)

This must be a problem with the Cache/proxy server at your end not properly verifying the server's last-modified date, therefore sending you stale content.  Our web server doesn't send these http headers:

Warning: 113 MHPAKAHC "Heuristic expiration"
Via: 1.1 MHPAKAHC (NetCache NetApp/5.6.2D13)

D.

> It seems the proxy is serving old content here- or might this be an issue with
> the eclipse HTTP client?

Just to be clear, we don't have any http cache/Proxy servers here at eclipse.org.

D.

Very clear. Seems funny though that the proxy didn't expire the data. Usually the response headers would tell the client/proxy how long the content is valid. Either this doesn't work or the proxy is misconfigured- unfortunately not something I could investigate/ influence.

(In reply to comment #8)
> Very clear. Seems funny though that the proxy didn't expire the data. Usually
> the response headers would tell the client/proxy how long the content is valid.

The HTTP 1.1 RFC suggests that although we can specify a max-age, it's the Proxy's job to ensure the content it serves is accurate. 

We don't set a max-age on our download server as it does not accurately represent the freshness of all the content, and we assume all proxies will check back (as they should)  :)

http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec13.html#sec13

D.

I've actually heard of this "incorrect cache" problem a couple of times, Denis. 

Do you remarks apply to HTTP 1.0 as well? (Could some intervening cache servers only support HTTP 1.0?) 

Would an especially safe and friendly host server use 'no-cache' in the HTTP response header?

(In reply to comment #10)
> I've actually heard of this "incorrect cache" problem a couple of times, Denis. 
Really?

> Do you remarks apply to HTTP 1.0 as well? (Could some intervening cache servers
> only support HTTP 1.0?) 

I guess so, but a cache server only supports 1.0 has bigger problems, IMO.


> Would an especially safe and friendly host server use 'no-cache' in the HTTP
> response header? 

Yes. One that has tons of bandwidth to waste, too  ;) 

D.

Yes, really :) 
I couldn't find the other bug, bug did find bug 84363 instead. 

And, as for bandwidth, I did just mean for the site.xml file, and the digest.zip. 

Its from one of those that the client "thinks" it needs the old jar that is no longer there.  And ... if I had not deleted the old file this weekend, I guess it would have been there, and the install would have been incorrect, so it is a bad problem, at least long term.
I think 144070 is related as well- problem went away when I retried without proxy.
